selection_rationale: In the many-clients, sparse-participation regime, client_fraction directly controls how many clients contribute per round (variance vs communication), learning rate governs per-round progress and stability with smaller aggregated updates, and momentum provides temporal smoothing that can counteract high variance from sparse sampling—especially beneficial with SFedAvg’s projected momentum.

configs.rationale: Increase sparsity to reduce communication while relying on strong momentum to stabilize fewer-client aggregation.
Scenario baseline as a reference point for acc_per_comm and convergence speed.
More clients per round to lower gradient variance and test scalability limits.
Very sparse participation with lower LR and stronger momentum to improve stability and smoothness.
Higher LR with reduced momentum to probe speed vs overshoot under sparse aggregation.
More clients with very strong momentum to combine lower variance and aggressive smoothing.
Moderate sparsity with strong momentum; expected to improve acc_per_comm for SFedAvg.
Slightly higher participation with lower momentum to evaluate sensitivity to smoothing strength.

expected_improvement: We expect SFedAvg to achieve higher accuracy per unit communication than FedAvg, especially with client_fraction in [0.08, 0.12], lr in [0.10, 0.12], and momentum ≥ 0.9; configurations with lower client_fraction and stronger momentum should yield smoother loss and improved acc_per_comm.
